0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• PedvaxHB(R) not recommended for use in the adult population
  • Invasive hemophilus influenzae type B infection; Prophylaxis: unvaccinated patients with functional or anatomic asplenia, sickle cell disease, or undergoing elective splenectomy: 1 dose IM
  • Invasive hemophilus influenzae type B infection; Prophylaxis: recipients of a hematopoietic stem cell transplant: 3-dose series IM to start 6 to 12 months after successful transplant; allow 4 weeks between doses

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono:
• usual dose: 2- or 3-dose primary series plus a booster dose at 12 to 15 months of age; for catch-up immunization, the number of doses depends on age of first vaccination and product used
  • Invasive hemophilus influenzae type B infection; Prophylaxis: ActHIB(R), 3-dose primary series IM at age 2, 4, and 6 months; booster at 15 to 18 months of age
  • Invasive hemophilus influenzae type B infection; Prophylaxis: PedvaxHIB(R),2-dose primary series IM; at age 2 and 4 months; booster at 12 to 15 months of age
  • Invasive hemophilus influenzae type B infection; Prophylaxis: (Hiberix(R); previously vaccinated, 15 to 59 months of age) booster dose, 1 dose IM
  • Invasive hemophilus influenzae type B infection; Prophylaxis: (ActHIB(R); previously unvaccinated, 7 to 11 months of age) 2 doses IM AND booster dose at 15 to 18 months of age; doses must be separated by 2 months
  • Invasive hemophilus influenzae type B infection; Prophylaxis: (ActHIB(R); previously unvaccinated, 12 to 14 months of age) 1 dose IM AND booster dose at 15 to 18 months of age; doses must be separated by 2 months
  • Invasive hemophilus influenzae type B infection; Prophylaxis: (ActHIB(R); previously unvaccinated, 15 months through 5 years) 1 dose IM
  • Invasive hemophilus influenzae type B infection; Prophylaxis: (PedvaxHIB(R); previously unvaccinated, 2 to 10 months of age) 2 doses IM AND booster dose at 12 to 15 months of age; doses must be separated by 2 months
  • Invasive hemophilus influenzae type B infection; Prophylaxis: (PedvaxHIB(R); previously unvaccinated, 11 to 14 months of age) 2 doses IM; doses must be separated by 2 months
  • Invasive hemophilus influenzae type B infection; Prophylaxis: (PedvaxHIB(R); previously unvaccinated, 15 to 71 months of age) 1 dose IM

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Invasive hemophilus influenzae type B infection; Prophylaxis

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• age less than 6 weeks
  • ActHIB(R): history of hypersensitivity to any vaccine component or to any component of whole-cell diphtheria toxoid/tetanus toxoid/pertussis vaccine or Tripedia(R) when combined by reconstitution
  • Hiberix(R): severe allergic reaction (eg, anaphylaxis) following any previous haemophilus influenzae type b, or tetanus toxoid-containing vaccine or any vaccine component
  • PedvaxHIB(R): hypersensitivity to a previous dose, to any component of the vaccine or the diluent, or symptoms suggestive of hypersensitivity

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• acute illness with or without fever, moderate or severe; defer vaccination unless the benefit of protection outweighs the risk of an adverse reaction
  • adults and children greater than 6 years of age; not recommended due to low risk of Haemophilus influenza B illness
  • antigenuria occurs; urine antigen detection may not have diagnostic value within 1 to 2 weeks after vaccination
  • Guillain-Barre syndrome, history of within 6 weeks of previous tetanus toxoid-containing vaccination; carefully consider the benefits and possible risks of any tetanus toxoid-containing vaccine
  • hypersensitivity reaction, including anaphylaxis may occur
  • IM administration only; avoid injecting into a blood vessel
  • immunosuppressed children; immune response to vaccine may be suboptimal
  • latex sensitivity; tip cap, rubber plunger, and/or vial stopper may contain natural latex rubber
  • report suspected adverse reactions to VAERS at 1-800-822-7967 or www.vaers.hhs.gov.

sub.title: Pregnancy Category
sub.mono:
• Haemophilus B Vaccine: C (FDA)
  • Haemophilus B Vaccine: B2 (AUS)

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Haemophilus B Vaccine: Micromedex: Infant risk is minimal.

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: Haemophilus b conjugate vaccine (meningococcal protein conjugate) is a polyribosylribitol phosphate (PRP) of Haemophilus influenza type b that is covalently bound to an outer membrane complex (OMPC) of Neisseria meningitidis serogroup B, which forms an antigen that stimulates antibody response and immunologic memory by converting the T-independent antigen into a T-dependent antigen.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    IM use only; do not inject IV, intradermally, or subQ
  • Intramuscular
    • shake well before use
    • inject into anterolateral aspect of the thigh or deltoid muscle; do not inject into the buttocks
    • ActHIB(R) reconstitute with 0.4% sodium chloride diluent; administer within 24 hours
    • Hiberix(R); reconstitute only with the supplied saline diluent; transfer the entire contents of the prefilled syringe of diluent into the vial of lyophilized vaccine; with the needle still inserted, vigorously shake; withdraw the entire contents of the vial (approximately 0.5 mL) back into the syringe for injection
    • Hiberix(R); administer promptly following reconstitution, or refrigerate and administer within 24 hours; if stored, shake vigorously again prior to administration
    • PedvaxHIB(R); ready to use; no dilution required

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• ActHIB
    Intramuscular Powder for Solution: 10 MCG
  • Hiberix
    Intramuscular Powder for Solution: 10 MCG
  • Pedvaxhib
    Intramuscular Solution: 7.5 MCG/0.5 ML

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Advise caregiver that it may take up to 2 wks for the child to develop immunity.
  • This drug may cause an injection site reaction or fever.
  • Inform caregiver of the importance of the child receiving the entire series of vaccinations. If a dose is missed, another appointment should be scheduled as soon as possible.
